./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Algorithm Pathway
This minibook is the knowledge I absorbed from the practice of algorithmic problems on LeetCode, HackerRank etc.
I conclude some general patterns to address some category of problems and what I want to note here more is about the thought process when I think of a solution.

bit-operation/summary.html.title: Summary

linked-list/summary.html.title: Summary
linked-list/summary.html.body:
Linked list is a quite common data structure. Although it is easy for insertion and deletion, but sometimes it can be very tricky to use, because for a current node, its context is just its next node and its previous one if any.
dummy head
I place dummy head as the first point, because I suppose it is quite convenient when handling some problems.

dummy head is as its name: it has no extra purpose, just for head.

It is useful when we construct a linked list from scratch or the real head node is possibly changed - delete, replace etc.
commonly-use operations
reverse
Always store the reversed linked list, say 'newHead`

Initial state: newHead = null, means empty list
Each iteration: 

node.next = newHead;
newHead = node;
Two pointers race
Please refer to section [Two pointers race]

linked-list/two-pointers-race.html.title: Two pointers race
linked-list/two-pointers-race.html.body:
Most of time, we need 2 pointers to traverse a linked list or two linked lists.
fast-slow pointers catch up
The fast pointer advance 2x steps while the slow one does per step.
check cycle in a linked list
A typical use of fast-slow pointers is to check a loop in a linked list. 

If there is a cycle in a linked list, there will be a point where the two pointers finally reach.


find the middle node
Another use of fast-slow pointers is to find the middle node of a linked list.
two pointers keeping a distance
Sometimes, we need to operate linked list from right to left, but normally single linked list can traverse from left to right. So if we keep two pointers in a distance, the problem will be simpler.
rightmost Nth node problem
Many problems need to do some operation from rightmost Nth node and I name it Rightmost Nth node problem.
Normally, we need to get the length of the linked list, and then we can know where we should stop when traversing the list.
But actually, it is unnecessary to waste time to get the length. When two pointers keep a distance n, and when a pointer reaches the tail, another pointer is just at the place we need.

align two pointers
When two linked lists have different lengths, how can we make two pointers aligned and then go ahead simultaneously?
It needs some tricks.

The key idea is when a pointer reaches the tail, the pointer will start from the head of another linked list.
At last, the two pointers will swap and keep aligned.
find the intersection point of two linked lists
When two linked list cross at some point, if only we can keep the two pointers aligned and step ahead simultaneously, then it becomes quite easy to find the cross point.

opposite pointers
Two pointers go ahead with opposite direction. One is from left to right, another from right to left.
Before that, sometimes there is a need to reverse the 2nd half of a linked list.
